positive_phenotypes: The patient presented with Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism, which is a clinical hallmark of Parkinson's disease.
The patient exhibited infantile-onset Parkinsonism, leukoencephalopathy, and intellectual disability.

The patient has infantile-onset neurodegeneration and Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism. The first family carried one of the alleles found in our patient (p.Trp13Gly), along with a frameshift mutation predicted to result in loss of function; the latter may account for the more severe intellectual disability seen in the affected siblings.
num_compound_or_double_hets: The patient had compound heterozygous mutations in WARS2, which are reported to cause different clinical manifestations.
The patient was compound heterozygous for two variants in the WARS2 gene.
The patient has compound heterozygous mutations in WARS2.
No compound or double heterozygotes were reported in the provided articles.

quote_snippets: compound heterozygous mutations in WARS2 (p.Trp13Gly, p.Ser228Trp)
infantile-onset, Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism at the age of 2 years
decreased steady-state WARS2 protein and normal OXPHOS content

The patient was evaluated at the NIH at age 9 and had advanced Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism with prominent and unpredictable 'on-off' fluctuations, peak-dose dyskinesia, stooped posture and disabling off-dystonia.
Qualitative evaluation of MRI spectroscopy revealed slightly low N-acetylaspartate (NAA) in the left frontal white matter compared to normal adults.
The patient underwent implantation of deep brain stimulator leads that resulted in substantial improvement in the motor complications of PD.

The first family carried one of the alleles found in our patient (p.Trp13Gly), along with a frameshift mutation predicted to result in loss of function; the latter may account for the more severe intellectual disability seen in the affected siblings.
This difference likely reflects the unique impact that a specific variant in WARS2 can have on the resulting cellular and clinical phenotype, or different methodologies.
The association of the patient’s WARS2 variants to Parkinsonism or PD may be further clarified by systematically interrogating available cohorts for such mutations.
de novo mutations causing sporadic early-onset Parkin-son's disease.
implicated in the etiology of autosomal recessive intellectual disability.
mutations in SLC25A4 cause severe early-onset mitochondrial dis-ease and loss of mitochondrial DNA copy number.
novel (ovario) leukodystrophy related to AARS2 mutations.
mutations in AARS2 in a series of CSF1R-negative patients with adult-onset leu-koencephalopathy with axonal spheroids and pigmented glia.
